org.ftccommunity.i2clibrary

Class I2cDeviceClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ftccommunity.i2clibrary.I2cDeviceClient
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.HardwareDevice, II2cDeviceClient, IOpModeStateTransitionEvents 

    public final class I2cDeviceClient
extends java.lang.Object
implements II2cDeviceClient, IOpModeStateTransitionEvents
    I2cDeviceClient is a utility class that makes it easy to read or write data to an instance of I2cDevice. There's a really whole lot of hard stuff this does for you

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.ftccommunity.i2clibrary.interfaces.II2cDeviceClient

        II2cDeviceClient.HeartbeatAction, II2cDeviceClient.READ_MODE, II2cDeviceClient.ReadWindow, II2cDeviceClient.TimestampedData

      Instantiate an I2cDeviceClient instance in the indicated device with the indicated initial window of registers being read.

      • I2cDeviceClient

        public I2cDeviceClient(com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode context,
                       II2cDevice i2cDevice,
                       int i2cAddr8Bit,
                       boolean closeOnOpModeStop)
        Instantiate an I2cDeviceClient instance in the indicated device with the indicated initial window of registers being read.
        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which the creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the device we are to be a client of
        i2cAddr8Bit - its 8 bit i2cAddress

      • arm

        public void arm()
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Arms the client for operation. This involves registering for callbacks with the underlying I2cDevice. Only one client of an I2cDevice may register for callbacks at any given time; if multiple clients exist, they must be coordinated so as to use the I2cDevice sequentially. This method is idempotent.
        Specified by:
        arm in interface II2cDeviceClient
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.disarm(), II2cDeviceClient.isArmed()

      • close

        public void close()
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Close down and disable this device. Once this is done, the object instance cannot support further read() or write() calls. Note that calling close() here does NOT also close() the underlying I2cDevice: we here are a *client* of the I2cDevice, not its owner. If your I2cDevice has a non-trivial close() semantic, you are yourself responsible for calling that method at an appropriate time.
        Specified by:
        close in interface com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.HardwareDevice
        Specified by:
        close in interface II2cDeviceClient

        Sets the set of I2C device registers that we wish to read.
        Specified by:

      • ensureReadWindow

        public void ensureReadWindow(II2cDeviceClient.ReadWindow windowNeeded,
                             II2cDeviceClient.ReadWindow windowToSet)
        Ensure that the current register window covers the indicated set of registers.
        Specified by:
        ensureReadWindow in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        windowNeeded - Test the current register window, if any, against this window to see if an update to the current register window is needed in order to cover it. May be null, indicating that an update to the current register window is always needed
        windowToSet - If an update to the current register window is needed, then this is the window to which it will be set. May be null.
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.setReadWindow(ReadWindow), II2cDeviceClient.read8(int)

      • readTimeStamped

        public II2cDeviceClient.TimestampedData readTimeStamped(int ireg,
                                                        int creg,
                                                        II2cDeviceClient.ReadWindow readWindowNeeded,
                                                        II2cDeviceClient.ReadWindow readWindowSet)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Advanced: Atomically calls ensureReadWindow() with the last two parameters and then readTimeStamped() with the first two without the possibility of a concurrent client interrupting in the middle.
        Specified by:
        readTimeStamped in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        ireg - the register number of the first byte register to read
        creg - the number of bytes / registers to read
        readWindowNeeded - the read window we require
        readWindowSet - the read window to set if the required read window is not current
        Returns:
        the data that was read, together with the timestamp
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.ensureReadWindow(ReadWindow, ReadWindow), II2cDeviceClient.readTimeStamped(int, int), II2cDeviceClient.executeFunctionWhileLocked(IFunc)

      • write8

        public void write8(int ireg,
                   int data,
                   boolean waitforCompletion)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Writes a byte to the indicated register. The call may or may block until the write has been issued to the device controller
        Specified by:
        write8 in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        ireg - the register number that is to be written
        data - the byte which is to be written to that register
        waitforCompletion - whether or not to wait until the write has been sent to the controller
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.write(int, byte[], boolean)

      • write

        public void write(int ireg,
                  byte[] data)
        Write data to a set of registers, beginning with the one indicated. The data will be written to the I2C device as expeditiously as possible. This method will not return until the data has been written to the device controller; however, that does not necessarily indicate that the data has been issued in an I2C write transaction, though that ought to happen a short deterministic time later.
        Specified by:
        write in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        ireg - the first of the registers which is to be written
        data - the data which is to be written to the registers
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.write8(int, int), II2cDeviceClient.write(int, byte[], boolean)

      • write

        public void write(int ireg,
                  byte[] data,
                  boolean waitForCompletion)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Writes data to a set of registers, beginning with the one indicated. The data will be written to the I2C device as expeditiously as possible. The call may or may block until the write has been issued to the device controller.
        Specified by:
        write in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        ireg - the first of the registers which is to be written
        data - the data which is to be written to the registers
        waitForCompletion - whether or not to wait until the write has been sent to the controller
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.write8(int, int, boolean)

        Specified by:

        Returns:
        the current I2C cycle count

      • setHeartbeatInterval

        public void setHeartbeatInterval(int msHeartbeatInterval)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Sets the interval within which communication must be received by the I2C device list a timeout may occur. The default heartbeat interval is zero, signifying that no heartbeat is maintained.
        Specified by:
        setHeartbeatInterval in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        msHeartbeatInterval - the new hearbeat interval, in milliseconds
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.getHeartbeatInterval()

      • getHeartbeatAction

        public II2cDeviceClient.HeartbeatAction getHeartbeatAction()
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Returns the current action, if any, to take upon expiration of the heartbeat interval.
        Specified by:
        getHeartbeatAction in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Returns:
        the current heartbeat action. May be null
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.setHeartbeatAction(HeartbeatAction)

      • setHeartbeatAction

        public void setHeartbeatAction(II2cDeviceClient.HeartbeatAction action)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Sets the action to take when the current heartbeat interval expires. The default action is null; thus, to be useful, an action must always be explicitly specified.
        Specified by:
        setHeartbeatAction in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        action - the action to take at each heartbeat.
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.getHeartbeatAction(), II2cDeviceClient.setHeartbeatInterval(int)

      • setThreadPriorityBoost

        public void setThreadPriorityBoost(int priorityBoost)
        Description copied from interface: II2cDeviceClient
        Sets the boost in thread priority we use for data acquisition. Judiciously applied, this boost can help reduce jitter in data timestamps.
        Specified by:
        setThreadPriorityBoost in interface II2cDeviceClient
        Parameters:
        priorityBoost - the boost in thread priority to apply
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.getThreadPriorityBoost()
